Part 1: Investigating the microscopic World

Resolving small structures¶

Light is a powerful tool for exploring structures, but its wavelength fundamentally limits the resolution achievable. At the end of the 16th century, the microscope was invented to resolve and observe small structures, initially mainly biological samples such as seeds, plants, the eye of a fly and the structure of cork. Hooke, one of the first to use a microscope described the pores inside the cork as ‘cells’, the origin of the current use of the word in biology today.

In the classical limit, the smallest detail resolvable by conventional microscopy is approximately half the wavelength (2λ\lambdaλ) of the light used. For visible light, this resolution limit is around 200-250 nanometers (nm), which is sufficient for resolving cells and large organelles, but far too large for atomic or molecular structures.

To resolve smaller structures like single crystals and individual atoms, which have characteristic spacings on the scale of ≈0.1\approx 0.1≈0.1 to 1 nm1 \text{ nm}1 nm (or 1 to 10 Angstroms10 \text{ Angstroms}10 Angstroms), researchers must use “light” with a much shorter wavelength. For this, X-rays are commonly used as these have wavelengths comparable to the interatomic spacing in crystals. This allows for the determination of the atomic structure of crystals down to resolutions of 0.1 nm0.1 \text{ nm}0.1 nm or better, effectively resolving the positions of the constituent atoms.

To resolve structures smaller than the size of an atom’s position, one must move beyond using light (photons) and instead employ beams of high-energy fundamental particles, such as electrons or other particles. The key principle remains the same as with light: to resolve a feature, the probe’s de Broglie wavelength (λ\lambdaλ) must be comparable to or smaller than the feature’s size. High-energy electrons can have de Broglie wavelengths of less than 0.004 nm0.004 \text{ nm}0.004 nm, significantly shorter than the atomic spacing of ≈0.1 nm\approx 0.1 \text{ nm}≈0.1 nm. This extremely small wavelength allows modern electron microscopes to not only resolve the regular positions of atoms in a crystal lattice but also to image individual atoms and distinguish different elements within a material, achieving resolutions approaching 0.05 nm0.05 \text{ nm}0.05 nm.

Equation

The de Broglie wavelength

In SI units (i.e. the international system of units International System of Units (2025)) the de Broglie wavelength is defined as:

λ=hp\lambda = \frac{h}{p} \\λ=ph​
(1)

Here, λ\lambdaλ is the wavelength, hhh is the Planck constant, ppp is the momentum with h=6.626×10−34m2h = 6.626 \times 10^{-34} m^2h=6.626×10−34m2 kg/s =6.626×10−34Js= 6.626 \times 10^{-34} J s =6.626×10−34Js

Nuclear and Particle physics requires going to even smaller scales: Electrons and protons are most often used in order to test the structure of matter. Even when accelerated to modest velocities, they can probe features much smaller than atoms.

The Geiger-Marsden experiment¶

The Geiger-Marsden experiment, also known as the Rutherford experiment, is an experiment conducted in 1909 by Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden under the guidance of Ernest Rutherford at the University of Manchester. The experiment was part of a series of experiments performed between 1906 and 1913 that investigated the atomic structure.

The experiment involved positively charged α\alphaα particles (Helium nuclei consisting of two protons and two neutrons) that were guided in a beam at a thin sheet of gold foil. The source of the α\alphaα particles was radium, as it was one of the most radioacive elements known at that time. Gold was chosen for the foil as it is the most malleable metal and therefore easiest material to manufacture a thin foil with. The deflection of the α\alphaα particles was measured using a phosphorescent screen surrounding the gold foil. Each particle impacting on the screen produced a tiny flash of light that was detected “by eye”: Geiger worked in a darkened laboratory for hours, counting the scintillations using a microscope and noting the results down.

The results showed that most alpha particles passed straight through the foil however some were deflected at large angles of more than 90 degrees and even up to 180 degrees. This disproved the plum pudding model of the atom that had been proposed by Thompson.

Rutherford drew the conclusion that atoms have a small, dense, positively charged nucleus as explained in his 1911 paperRutherford (1911) that eventually led to the widespread use of scattering in particle physics to study subatomic matter. The paper was primarily about alpha particle scattering in an era before particle scattering was a primary tool for physics.

In the following we will see how scattering experiments are used as a tool to understand the basic constituents of matter. The Geiger Marsden experiment is used to demonstrate the basic principles of these measurements.

Calculation

Scattering angle in the Geiger Marsden Experiment

From the scattering measured in the experiment, we can deduce something on the relationship of the α\alphaα particles and the gold atoms (or the scattering centre).

From the above calculation using energy and momentum conservation, we deduce the following relationship:

vt′2(1−mtmα)=vα′vt′cos⁡θ{v'^2_t} \left(1 - \frac{m_t}{m_\alpha}\right) = {v'_\alpha}{v'_t} \cos\thetavt′2​(1−mα​mt​​)=vα′​vt′​cosθ
(6)

We can analyse the equation without even knowing much about the concrete values:

Looking at the right-hand side, we find we have the multiplication of two velocities - this product is for sure positive (as there are not negative velocities). The other term on the right-hand side is cos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθ which is positive between -90° and +90°. However, cos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθ is negative for any angles larger than 90°. So the right-hand side takes on a \textit{negative} value for scattering angles larger than 90°. This of course means, that also the left-hand side needs to be negative in these cases.

Therefore, let’s take a look at the left-hand side of the equation. Again, vt′2{v'^2_t}vt′2​ will always be positive, so (1−mtmα)\left(1 - \frac{m_t}{m_\alpha}\right)(1−mα​mt​​) needs to be negative, i.e. zero is larger than the left-hand side:

0>(1−mtmα)mtmα>1mt>mα\begin{align*} 0&>\left(1 - \frac{m_t}{m_\alpha}\right)\\ \frac{m_t}{m_\alpha} &> 1\\ m_t &> m_\alpha \end{align*}0mα​mt​​mt​​>(1−mα​mt​​)>1>mα​​
(7)

This shows that the target mass is larger than that of the α\alphaα particle. In fact it’s much larger by roughly a factor of 40: M(Au) ∼\sim∼ 40 ×\times× M(alpha). This indicates, there is a solid heavy “ball” inside the atom, not a soft distributed mass.

There is more we can learn, again using energy conservation. When the positively charged α\alphaα particle approaches the also positively charged gold nucleus it experiences a repelling force and as a consequence its kinetic energy gets converted into potential energy until it (equivalent to a ball that is tossed into the air with an initial velocity, its kinetic energy gets converted into potential energy in the gravitational field of the earth until its velocity at its highest point is zero, at which point it turns to be accelerated by the gravitational towards earth).

Using this approach we can estimate the size of an atomic nuclei as we can estimate how close the α\alphaα particles get towards it.

Calculation

Distance of closest approach in the Geiger Marsden Experiment

The potential energy of the alpha particle with charge qαq_\alphaqα​ at a distance rrr from the gold nuclei with charge QAUQ_{\textrm{AU}}QAU​ is:

U=Epot=qαQAU4πϵ0rU = E_\textrm{pot} = \frac{q_\alpha Q_{\textrm{AU}}}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r}U=Epot​=4πϵ0​rqα​QAU​​
(8)

(see also PHY11006 lecture notes: \textit{5.5 The Potential and Potential Energy of a System of Charges})

The α\alphaα particles and the gold nuclei repell each other as they are both positively charged. In order to estimate how close they can get, we can compare the kinetic energy of the α\alphaα particles to the potential energy caused by the charges. The kinetic energy is “used up” in order to overcome the repelling force of the electric field of the nuclei. Thus, the Kinetic energy (at t=0, i.e. when the particle approach from infinity) and potential energy are equal at the “distance of closest approach”, the point at which the α\alphaα particles are the closest to the gold nuclei, before they are deflected away from the nuclei.

The kinetic energy of the α\alphaα particles in the Geiger Marsden experiment is Ekin=5.30E_\textrm{kin} = 5.30Ekin​=5.30 MeV. The charges of the α\alphaα particles and the gold nuclei are qα=2q_\alpha = 2qα​=2e and QAU=79Q_\textrm{AU}=79QAU​=79e respectively.

Ekin=EpotEkin=qαQAU4πϵ0r          ∣÷Ekin;×rr=qαQAU4πϵ0Ekin=2×79×(1.602×10−19)2C25.30×1.602×10−19x106J×9×109Nm2C2=4.3×10−14m=43fm\begin{align*} E_\textrm{kin} &= E_\textrm{pot} \\ E_\textrm{kin} &= \frac{q_\alpha Q_{\textrm{AU}}}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r} \; \; \; \; \; \biggr\rvert \div E_\textrm{kin} ; \times r \\ r &= \frac{q_\alpha Q_{\textrm{AU}}}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 E_\textrm{kin}}\\ &= \frac{2 \times 79 \times (1.602 \times 10^{-19})^2 C^2 }{5.30 \times 1.602 \times 10^{-19} x 10^6 J} \times 9\times 10^9 \frac{N m^2}{C^2}\\ &= 4.3 \times 10^{-14} m \\ &= 43 fm \end{align*}Ekin​Ekin​r​=Epot​=4πϵ0​rqα​QAU​​∣∣​÷Ekin​;×r=4πϵ0​Ekin​qα​QAU​​=5.30×1.602×10−19x106J2×79×(1.602×10−19)2C2​×9×109C2Nm2​=4.3×10−14m=43fm​
(9)

The α\alphaα particles do not come closer than 43 fm to the nucleus - the nucleus therefore is smaller than this! (Compare with the Bohr radius of 0.053 nm which is ∼\sim∼1000 larger)

General Basics of scattering experiments in High energy physics¶

Particle physics uses a specific system of units which is designed to make calculations easier - This is in contrast to the system of units that is normally used within physics, the International System of Units (SI) (International System of Units (2025)) which is metric and what you have been dealing with so far (and in future too).

Energy is generally measured in electron-Volt (eV). An electron volt is defined as the amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron after being accelerated from rest through an electric potential difference of 1 Volt in vacuum:

Ekin=q⋅VE_{\textrm{kin}} = q \cdot VEkin​=q⋅V
(10)

where EkinE_{\textrm{kin}}Ekin​ is the kinetic energy of the electron, qqq is its charge and VVV is the voltage (or voltage difference) with which it is accelerated. Given this definition, 1 eV =1.602×10−19= 1.602 \times 10^{-19}=1.602×10−19 J. So to convert from Joule into eV, one has to divide by 1.602×10−19 1.602 \times 10^{-19}1.602×10−19.

The unit eV is used to not only measure energy but also to measure momentum and mass. In particle physics, the relationship between energy, momentum and mass is derivated using special relativity and can be expressed in this simple formula:

Equation

Relativistic relationship between energy, momentum and mass

E2=p2c2+m2c4E^2 = p^2 c^2 + m^2 c^4 \\E2=p2c2+m2c4
(11)

Here, EEE is the energy, ppp is momentum, mmm is mass and ccc is the speed of light. In the case, that the kinetic energy of a particle can be neglected with respect to its mass, E=mc2E=mc^2E=mc2, the well-known Einstein formula. In cases, where the kinetic energy of a particle excess its mass, we can write E=pcE=pcE=pc. For most of the cases in this course, we will use E=pcE=pcE=pc unless stated otherwise.

Given the relativistic relationship between energy, momentum and mass, the unit of momentum is eV/ccc, whilst mass is eV/c2c^2c2

Example

Example: Mass of the Proton

mc2=1.67×10−27kg×(3×108m/s)2=1.5×10−9J1.5×10−9J=1.5×10−9/1.6×10−19  eV=939    MeV\begin{align*} m c^2 &= 1.67 \times 10^{-27} kg \times \left( 3 \times 10^8 m/s \right)^2 = 1.5 \times 10^{-9} J \\ 1.5 \times 10^{-9} J &= 1.5 \times 10^{-9} / 1.6 \times 10^{-19}\; \textrm{eV} = 939 \;\; \textrm{MeV} \end{align*}mc21.5×10−9J​=1.67×10−27kg×(3×108m/s)2=1.5×10−9J=1.5×10−9/1.6×10−19eV=939MeV​
(12)

Cross-sections and their measurement¶

What is a cross-section?¶

In the Geiger-Marsden experiment, whilst some α\alphaα particles are scattered by large angle, others are not deflected at all. As we have seen, from the general considerations, we can determine an upper limit on the size of the gold atoms.

For the α\alphaα particles, that are passing a gold foil, one can define the inclusive (or integral) cross-section as the area σ=πr2\sigma = \pi r^2σ=πr2 of the nuclei through which the α\alphaα particles need to pass to be scattered by an detectable angle θ\thetaθ. This is a generalisable definition: The cross section is used to quantify the effective size or the strength of an interaction with a particle. It does depend on the particle type as the size of the α\alphaα particle and the gold nuclei play a role.

As we have calculated above, the radius and thus the area of a nuclei are very small (∼\sim∼ femto metres). Physicists during the second world war decided to invent a new unit for the cross sectional area of nuclei and nuclear reactions, one that would also be a bit more natural in size, and tried to come up with a name. They settled on “barns” (due to the rural background of one of the physicists involved and because some of the cross-sections were as large as a barn). Today barn is used all fields of high-energy physics a unit of area which is used in cross-sections and integrated luminosity.

One barn (abbr. b) is equal to 10−28^{-28}−28 m2^22 or 10−24^{-24}−24 cm2^22. This is a larger area, common are cross-section smaller than mb or nb (millibarns and nanobarns). Easiest to remember is probably 1 pb = 10−12^{-12}−12 b = 10−36^{-36}−36 cm2^22

Measurement of cross-sections¶

How can we determine a cross-section? The easiest way to conceptualize how cross-sections and their measurements work, is to look at inclusive (or integral) cross-section. Figure a) demonstrates the principle of the measurement of an inclusive cross-section. Consider a flux of particles J=ΔN/ΔtJ = \Delta N / \Delta tJ=ΔN/Δt passes though the a target (in Rutherford: the foil). The particle flux decreases as:

ΔJ=−JσincnbΔx=−JσincNb\Delta J = -J \sigma_{inc} n_b \Delta x = -J \sigma_{inc} N_bΔJ=−Jσinc​nb​Δx=−Jσinc​Nb​

with J being the flux, σinc\sigma_{inc}σinc​ the inclusive cross-section, nbn_bnb​ the particle density in the target and Δx\Delta xΔx being the thickness of the target. nbΔxn_b \Delta xnb​Δx is therefore effectively the number of target particles in the path of the flux (the number of particles passing in a unit of time). Basically you determine the inclusive cross-section by measuring how many particle where scattered out of the beam. This is corresponding to the rate of particles being scattered depending on initial flux, target particles and cross-section.

a) Measurement of the integral cross section σ\sigmaσ. (b) Measurement of the differential cross section dσ\sigmaσ/dΩ\OmegaΩ (taken from Demtröder (2006))

The differential cross-section is determined as the particles flux scattered into the solid angle ΔΩ\Delta \OmegaΔΩ accepted by the detector. It is demonstrate in Fig b) where a detector detects the flux of particles being scattered into its acceptance and can be expressed as:

ΔJJA=nbΔxdσdΩΔΩ\frac{\Delta J}{J A} = n_b \Delta x \frac{ d \sigma}{d \Omega} \Delta \OmegaJAΔJ​=nb​ΔxdΩdσ​ΔΩ
(13)

with JJJ as the flux, A the area of the detector, nbΔxn_b \Delta xnb​Δx the number of target particles, dσdΩ\frac{ d \sigma}{d \Omega}dΩdσ​ the differential cross-section which depends on the interaction potential between the scattering particles A and B. ΔJJA\frac{\Delta J}{J A}JAΔJ​ is the fraction of incident particles that is scattered into the solid angle ΔΩ\Delta \OmegaΔΩ accepted by the detector.

The interpretation of the Geiger-Marsden experiment by Rutherford¶

As seen above, the mass of the nucleus is much larger than the mass of the α\alphaα particles. So when Rutherford looked into deriving a formula to describe the scattering occuring the Geiger-Marsden experiment, he assumed, there is no energy loss in the collision, that is he ignores the recoil of the target atom. It also seems, that the electrons have no impact on the scattering as the size of the nucleus, the scattering centre is so much smaller than that of the atoms. Under these conditions, the α\alphaα particle and nucleus interact through a central force, a physical problem studied already by Isaac Newton and that you have covered in Lecture 8, Y1 Mechanics (2025). This problem considers a central force that only acts along a line between the particles and where the force varies with the inverse square, like Coulomb force in this case.

As shown in Lecture 8, Y1 Mechanics (2025), a potential of the form V=k/rV = k/rV=k/r will lead to the following relationship between the scattering angle and the impact parameter bbb:

cosθ2=m2bkcos \frac{\theta}{2} = \frac{m^2 b}{k}cos2θ​=km2b​
(14)

with θ\thetaθ being the scattering angle (note: Lecture 8, Y1 Mechanics (2025) this is called ϕ\phiϕ, but in particle physics this angle is always called θ\thetaθ), mmm the mass of the α\alphaα particles, kkk the parameters of the potential and bbb the impact parameter or the point of closest approach, which is the vertical distance between the alpha particle’s initial trajectory and the nucleus.

While bbb might be a reasonable quantity to use in astronomical problems (Kepler used the same approach to calculate the movement of celestial bodies), it is not possible to measure bbb in the Geiger-Marsden experiment. Therefore, the challenge is to find a way to relate the scattering angle to a quantity that can actually be measured in these sorts of scattering experiments and this is what Rutherford did to explain the experiment.

The procedure is the following:

  • express the fraction of the flux passing through the band/annular bbb and deflected by an angle θ\thetaθ

  • compare this to the general expression for the differential cross section

  • connect it to the expression of the impact parameter derived using angular momentum and the potential (Lecture 8, Y1 Mechanics (2025))

Geometrical layout of the Geiger-Marsden experiment as used by Rutherford (taken from Demtröder (2006))

Calculation

Rutherford scattering angle

From geometrical considerations (i.e. just defining the rate of particles scattered into a solid angle without assuming anything more on the geometry) we can see that that:

ΔJJA=nGΔxdσdΩΔΩ\begin{align*} \frac{\Delta J}{J A} = n_G \Delta x \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} \Delta \Omega \end{align*}JAΔJ​=nG​ΔxdΩdσ​ΔΩ​
(15)

This is the general form of the differental cross-section.

Let us now assume a parallel beam of incident particles α\alphaα with particle flux density J (with J = dN/dt) that passes through a layer of particles B in rest with density nGn_\textrm{G}nG​. All particles α\alphaα that pass through an annular with radius bbb and width dbbb around an atom G are deflected by the angle θ±dθ/2\theta \pm \textrm{d}\theta/2θ±dθ/2. This assumes a sperically symmetric interaction potential: There is no prefered direction (along the ring with radius bbb). Per second, dJ=JdA=dN/dtdA=dN/dt2πbdb dJ = J dA = dN/dt dA = dN/dt 2\pi b dbdJ=JdA=dN/dtdA=dN/dt2πbdb particles α\alphaα pass through the annular ring (with A being the area). The fraction of all particles α\alphaα (incident per unit area and per second onto the target) scattered through an interaction with one single particle G into the range of deflection angles θ±dθ/2\theta \pm \textrm{d}\theta/2θ±dθ/2 is therefore:

dJ(θ±1/2  dθ)J=2πbdb=2πbdbdθdθ\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d} J (\theta \pm 1/2 \; \mathrm{d}\theta)}{J} = 2 \pi b \textrm{d}b = 2 \pi b \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \end{align*}JdJ(θ±1/2dθ)​=2πbdb=2πbdθdb​dθ​
(16)

If we place a detector with an area AD=R2dΩ=R2sin⁡θdθdϕA_D = R^2 \mathrm{d}\Omega = R^2 \sin\theta \mathrm{d}\theta\mathrm{d}\phiAD​=R2dΩ=R2sinθdθdϕ in a distance RRR from the scattering centre G, then this detector receives a fraction of the particles scattered by this one particle G:

dJ(θ,ϕ)Jdϕ2π=bdbdθdθdϕ\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d} J (\theta, \phi)}{J} \frac{\textrm{d}\phi}{2\pi} = b \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \textrm{d} \phi \end{align*}JdJ(θ,ϕ)​2πdϕ​=bdθdb​dθdϕ​
(17)

The fraction of all incident particles α\alphaα, scattered by all atoms G with density nGn_GnG​ in the volume VVV = AΔxA \Delta xAΔx is then:

dJ(θ,dΩ)J=nGAΔxbdbdθdθdϕ\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d} J (\theta, \textrm{d}\Omega)}{J} &= n_G A \Delta x b \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \textrm{d} \phi \end{align*}JdJ(θ,dΩ)​​=nG​AΔxbdθdb​dθdϕ​
(18)

This is a specific cross-section (in terms of geometry) that takes into account the impact paramter bbb and the scattering angle θ\thetaθ. We can compared it to (15) and find:

dJJ=nGAΔxbdbdθdθdϕ=nGAΔxdσdΩΔΩ\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d} J}{J} &= n_G A \Delta x b \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \textrm{d} \phi \\ &= n_G A \Delta x \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} \Delta \Omega \end{align*}JdJ​​=nG​AΔxbdθdb​dθdϕ=nG​AΔxdΩdσ​ΔΩ​
(19)

Setting these two equal yields:

nGAΔxbdbdθdθdϕ=nGAΔxdσdΩΔΩ∣  usingΔΩ=sin⁡θdθdϕdbdθdθdϕ=dσdΩsin⁡θdθdϕ\begin{align*} \cancel{n_G A \Delta x} b \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \textrm{d} \phi & = \cancel{n_G A \Delta x} \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} \Delta \Omega &\biggr\rvert \; \textrm{using} \Delta \Omega = \sin \theta \mathrm{d}\theta \mathrm{d}\phi \\ \frac{\textrm{d}b}{\textrm{d} \theta} \textrm{d} \theta \textrm{d} \phi & = \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} \sin \theta \mathrm{d}\theta \mathrm{d}\phi \end{align*}nG​AΔx​bdθdb​dθdϕdθdb​dθdϕ​=nG​AΔx​dΩdσ​ΔΩ=dΩdσ​sinθdθdϕ​∣∣​usingΔΩ=sinθdθdϕ
(20)

This gives a relationship between the differential cross-section and the impact parameter and scattering angle:

dσdΩ=bdbdθ1sin⁡θ\begin{align*} \boxed{\frac{\mathrm{d} \sigma}{\mathrm{d}\Omega} = b \frac{ \mathrm{d} b}{\mathrm{d} \theta} \frac{1}{\sin \theta}} \end{align*}dΩdσ​=bdθdb​sinθ1​​​
(21)

Measuring the relative fraction ΔJJ\frac{\Delta J}{J}JΔJ​ yields the differential cross section (see (15)) and with it the interaction potential as we have seen that the angle θ\thetaθ is defined as (see eq. (72) of the mechanics lecture notes):

cot⁡θ2=mv02bk=mv02b14πϵ0qQ\begin{align*} \cot\frac{\theta}{2} = \frac{m v_0^2 b}{k} = \frac{m v_0^2 b}{1} \frac{4 \pi \epsilon_0}{qQ} \end{align*}cot2θ​=kmv02​b​=1mv02​b​qQ4πϵ0​​​
(22)

Note, that the mechanics lecture notes eq. (72) use ϕ\phiϕ - this is the same angle, just a different name. For scattering angles, especially in particle physics, the angle is θ\thetaθ, so this is what we use here. We can re-arrage the equation to get the relationship for bbb:

cot⁡θ2=mv02b14πϵ0qQb=cotθ2qQmv024πϵ0\begin{align*} \cot\frac{\theta}{2} &= \frac{m v_0^2 b}{1} \frac{4 \pi \epsilon_0}{qQ} \\ b &= cot\frac{\theta}{2} \frac{qQ}{m v_0^2 4 \pi \epsilon_0} \end{align*}cot2θ​b​=1mv02​b​qQ4πϵ0​​=cot2θ​mv02​4πϵ0​qQ​​

We from this last equation we can also get dbdθ\frac{\mathrm{d}b}{\mathrm{d}\theta}dθdb​ by taking the derivative:

dbdθ=−1sin⁡2(θ/2)qQmv024πϵ0\begin{align*} \frac{\mathrm{d}b}{\mathrm{d}\theta} &= -\frac{1}{\sin^2(\theta/2)} \frac{qQ}{m v_0^2 4 \pi \epsilon_0} \end{align*}dθdb​​=−sin2(θ/2)1​mv02​4πϵ0​qQ​​

As bbb cannot be measured, we eliminated it from from (21) by inserting the above expression for bbb and use sin⁡(2θ)=2sin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)\sin(2\theta) = 2 \sin(\theta) \cos(\theta)sin(2θ)=2sin(θ)cos(θ):

This is the formula for Rutherford scattering!!

This formula analytically describes Rutherford scattering which is the elastic scattering of charged particles by the Coulomb interaction, sometimes also called Coulomb scattering.

Elastic and inelastic collisions¶

Rutherford scattering is elastic scattering, but in this module we will also be looking at inelastic scattering so it’s important to understand, what the difference is. In a scattering process momentum is conserved but this is not always the case for the kinetic energy and this is where the difference lies.

In elastic collisions, the kinetic energy is conserved in addition to the momentum (e.g. snooker balls, Rutherford scattering). In these cases, you write down an equation for the energies of the particles before and after the collision and a second equation with the momenta of the particles before and after the collision {--} this later calculation can be done vectorially (i.e. under consideration of the angles of the particles). The final momenta depend on the angle of scattering and given θ\thetaθ we can calculate the velocities of the outgoing particles. If you look at the outcome of scattering experiments such that the Rutherford experiment, and you fix the scattering angle that you are looking at as well as the incident particle energy, you will find peaks in the spectrum of the scattered particle energies.

In inelastic collisions however, the kinetic energy is not conserved (though total energy is conserved!) and is transformed into heat or other mechanical energy (e.g. car crash) or in particle collisions into mass. Effectively, the equation for energy conservation then reads:

Ekininitial=Ekinfinal+EinternalE^\textrm{initial}_\textrm{kin} = E^\textrm{final}_\textrm{kin} + E_\textrm{internal}Ekininitial​=Ekinfinal​+Einternal​

where EinternalE_\textrm{internal}Einternal​ describes the energy transformed into heat or the production of another particle. If looking at scattering of particles, you will then see a number of peaks that correspond to different values of Ekininitial−EinternalE^\textrm{initial}_\textrm{kin} - E_\textrm{internal}Ekininitial​−Einternal​. The internal energy is expanded for exciting the nuclei or to produce new particles.

Scattering on nucleons¶

The scattering experiments did not stop with Rutherford scattering: For very large angles (corresponding to small impact parameters where the electrons are very close to the centre of the atom and thus the nucleus) again deviations from the Rutherford formula were observed.

In these follow up experiments from the original Geiger-Marsden experiment, α\alphaα particles were scattered of various light nuclei and the experimenters used new materials as sources of α\alphaα particle which higher energies. Using higher energies for the incoming α\alphaα particles corresponds to shorter wavelengths and smaller structures being probed in these experiments.

Comparison of Rutherford (or Coulomb) scattering of particles to the measured data (taken from Demtröder (2006))

When comparing the number of counts as function of energy of the incoming particle or as function of the angle to the predicted count from the Rutherford Scattering formula, a deviation at high energies and large angles became apparent. Finally, the analysis of these results led to the conclusion that the alpha particle was penetrating the nucleus in these cases. Once probe come closer than radius of nulei, a new short range force, called the nuclear force, becomes important. Scattering calculated based on Coulomb potential is no longer valid. The attractive nuclear force is much stronger. **This deviation from the prediction based on a specific scattering potential is an important evidence that the potential (or force) probed at that energy **

In the following decades, with the advent of particle accelerators, the particle beams used in scattering experiments became more powerful. This triggered an era of scattering experiments with nucleons and an effort to understand the nucleus.

Initially, the results were very similar to Rutherford scattering, exhibiting a signature of elastic scattering as shown in the following figure. Here, since the incoming energy and the scattering angle are fixed, the energy of the outgoing electrons is fixed as well. In this measurement, there are two peaks visible: The scattering of electrons on electrons (in the atomic shell) and of electrons with a proton or neutron from the nucleus.

Energy spectrum of 15.7 Mev electrons scattered at 30° by polystyrene (carbon). The ordinate (y-axis) represents the observed count as a function of an arbitrary energy unit on the x-axis (i.e. in this case the setting on the magnetic analyzer that selects out the energy of the scattered electrons). The counters have a 3 percent resolution in energy (taken from Lyman et al. (1951))

However with increasing energy and depending on the investigated materials, more complicated scattering patterns emerged as in the following figure, where apart from the elastic scattering peak, there are various other peaks visible that correspond to different excited states of Carbon.

The elastic and inelastic peaks at 187 Mev in carbon at a scattering angle of 80°. (taken from Fregeau & Hofstadter (1955))

Deep inelastic scattering and the discovery of proton substructure¶

In the 1960s, several sites around the world conducted scattering experiments to investigate the structure of the nucleus, that had been determined to be indeed a vaguely uniformly charged sphere. The details of the shape of the nucleus (size, charge distribution etc.) was determined in scattering experiments. The involved potential and cross-section formulae are much more involved than the one for Rutherford scattering, so these are covered in more advanced courses.

In 1966, the Stanford Linear Accelerator, a 3.2 km (2 mi) linear accelerator, was constructed to accelerate electrons to energies of 50 GeV. It is situated on Stanford University-owned land on Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, California, just west of the university’s main campus. Inelastic electron scattering was measured with three spectrometers in SLAC End Station A. A beam of electrons with energy EEE passed through a liquid hydrogen target. Electrons that rebounded at a preselected angle θ\thetaθ into the acceptance of the spectrometer were analyzed for their momentum. For each given set of values EEE and θ\thetaθ, a series of measurements were made covering using the instrument, that already made heavy use of computer.

Experiments conducted in 1968 at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC) and published on October 20, 1969, showed that the proton contained much smaller, point-like objects and was therefore not an elementary particle. The results no longer matching what was expected for elastic collisions on nucleons and were instead consistent with proton sub-structure. Quarks were confirmed as constituents of the proton.

Results of electron scattering experiments discovering the substructure of the atom (left) and the proton (right). Note, that the results on the right are from the scattering of electrons on the atom and therefore deviate from the previously shown results of Rutherford scattering as negatively charged particles scatter of the atom, given a slightly different form of the potential (taken from Halzen & Martin (1984)).
